body:
Aside from this bug, I would like to ask what is the recommended method for pipelining multiple transformers which each transformer only transforms specified columns. For example, below code is working fine for me but I think one can use the above code to accomplish the same job (if the bug fixed ofc).  I am using `ColumnwiseTransformer` instead of `ColumnTransformer` in the below code and it works perfectly for `predict` and `update`

```python
from sktime.transformations.series.boxcox import LogTransformer
from sktime.transformations.series.exponent import ExponentTransformer
from sktime.datasets import load_longley
from sktime.forecasting.sarimax import SARIMAX
from sktime.forecasting.model_selection import temporal_train_test_split
from sktime.transformations.compose import OptionalPassthrough, ColumnwiseTransformer

y, X = load_longley()
y_train, y_test, X_train, X_test = temporal_train_test_split(y, X)

selected_columns_1 = ["GNP", "UNEMP"]
selected_columns_2 = ["GNPDEFL"]


transformer1 = ColumnwiseTransformer(LogTransformer(), columns=selected_columns_1)
transformer2 = ColumnwiseTransformer(ExponentTransformer(), columns=selected_columns_2)

pipe = transformer1 * transformer2
model = pipe ** SARIMAX()
model.fit(y_train, X_train)

# Gives ValueError if OptionalPassthrough is not used
model.predict(fh=[1, 2, 3, 4], X=X_test)

# Gives TypeError either way
model.update(y=y_test.iloc[:2], X=X_test.iloc[:2, :])
```

- Moreover, I have tried to use `ColumnSelect` to do the same job but it only transformed selected columns and drop the rest. Hence, I can't use it in the transformer pipeline.

```python
transformer1 = LogTransformer()[["GNP", "UNEMP"]]
transformer2 = ExponentTransformer()["GNPDEFL"]

pipe = transformer1 * transformer2
```

@ilkersigirci, you can use a combination of `ColumnSelect` and `FeatureUnion` to do this!

Here's with dunders:
```python
from sktime.transformations.series.boxcox import LogTransformer
from sktime.transformations.series.exponent import ExponentTransformer
from sktime.datasets import load_longley
from sktime.forecasting.sarimax import SARIMAX
from sktime.forecasting.model_selection import temporal_train_test_split
from sktime.transformations.compose import OptionalPassthrough, ColumnwiseTransformer

y, X = load_longley()
y_train, y_test, X_train, X_test = temporal_train_test_split(y, X)

selected_columns_1 = ["GNP", "UNEMP"]
selected_columns_2 = ["GNPDEFL"]

transformer1 = LogTransformer()
transformer2 = ExponentTransformer()

model = (transformer1[selected_columns_1] + transformer2[selected_columns_2] ) ** SARIMAX()

model.fit(y_train, X_train)

model.predict(fh=[1, 2, 3, 4], X=X_test)

model.update(y=y_test.iloc[:2], X=X_test.iloc[:2, :])
```

What the model does, it appies `transformer1` to `GNP`, `UNEMP` cols, `transformer2` to `GNPDEFL`, and drops other columns, in the exogeneous data, then applies `SARIMAX` to the transformed `X_train`/`X_test`, and the original `y_train`.

If you want to pass through columns unchanged, you can use the `Id` transformer.

regarding the compositors, I am baffled that there are actually two column transformers in `sktime` - on my mental map, I only had the one in `transformations.compose`.

The one in `panel.compose` seems to be still following the legacy architecture, and it is no wonder that it throws data input checks etc. But it has more parameters, perhaps that's why it was left in order to have them refactor/merged?

We may just want to replace it by a `_DelegatedTransformer` which under the hood uses the dunders?

Here: https://github.com/sktime/sktime-tutorial-pydata-global-2022
all the notebooks are available on binder, you will probably be interested in part 2.

Not sure if the video is already online, but if not it should be released very soon!

I think it would be a better approach  if `ColumnSelect` has a `passthrough` parameter (or similar functionality) when using in the pipeline. This enables us to make the transformation to some columns in one pipeline step but also allow other columns to be used with transformers in the next steps. What do you think @fkiraly ?

>  I don't want to drop untransformed columns, instead I want to give them to the model. I think I can't use ColumnSelect for this and it seems the only option is using ColumnwiseTransformer. Or did I miss something obvious?

How you can do that is what I meant with

> If you want to pass through columns unchanged, you can use the Id transformer.

So like this:

```python

from sktime.transformations.series.boxcox import LogTransformer
from sktime.transformations.series.exponent import ExponentTransformer
from sktime.datasets import load_longley
from sktime.forecasting.sarimax import SARIMAX
from sktime.forecasting.model_selection import temporal_train_test_split
from sktime.transformations.compose import Id

y, X = load_longley()
y_train, y_test, X_train, X_test = temporal_train_test_split(y, X)

selected_columns_1 = ["GNP", "UNEMP"]
selected_columns_2 = ["GNPDEFL"]
other_columns = ["ARMED", "POP"]

transformer1 = LogTransformer()
transformer2 = ExponentTransformer()

model = (transformer1[selected_columns_1] + transformer2[selected_columns_2] + Id()[other_columns]) ** SARIMAX()

model.fit(y_train, X_train)

model.predict(fh=[1, 2, 3, 4], X=X_test)

model.update(y=y_test.iloc[:2], X=X_test.iloc[:2, :])
```

But I agree, the kind of idea you just suggested - via `ColumnTransformer` and `passthrough` - might make it easier to write things like this down.

I'm not quite sure about the most compact way for a specification syntax though - do you want to give it a try and just write down how in your mind it might look like to define an estimator like that? I'll also think a bit about the "desired end state" here.

@ilkersigirci, thanks for the notebook vignette!

> Btw, I am wondering why we aren't considering `ColumnwiseTransformer` approach (which is working as intended as can be seen in the first message). Is the `FeatureUnion` with `ColumnSelect` approach is more preferable?

No particular reason, except that the latter work out of the box with dunders.
I also wouldn't say I'm not considering it, I just showed another way to do it.

What would be your preferred option (for it to work) if you could spell it out?
Feel free to "invent" code that doesn't run with current `sktime` but you think would be nice.

From your colab notebook, do I understand correctly:

* you would like that `ColumnTransformer` can be used just like `ColumnEnsembleForecaster`, possibly including a passthrough option
* you may like something like `ColumnSelect` that *keeps* the other columns instead of discarding them? E.g., a `keep_other_columns` parameter or similar (default=`False`

?

>    You may like something like `ColumnSelect` that _keeps_ the other columns instead of discarding them? E.g., a `keep_other_columns` parameter or similar (default=`False`
> 

My preferred way is exactly this @fkiraly. Although this transformer isn't hard to implement, I haven't figured out how it can be used with dunders. Actually, at first look, I thought `ColumnSelect` works as you described above. It seems more intuitive for me.

Another approach that come to my mind would be adding `selected_columns:Optional[List[str]] = None` parameter to `BaseTransformer`. By default it is `None` and this would mean that the transformer will be applied to all columns. But if `selected_columns` is other than `None`, the transformer only transform those columns and passthrough rest.


Example code.
```python
from sktime.transformations.series.boxcox import LogTransformer
from sktime.datasets import load_longley

_, X = load_longley()
transformer = Log(offset=1, selected_columns=["GNPDEFL"])

# Should only transform `GNPDEFL` and passthrough other columns.
transformer.fit_transform(X)
```

This approach is already implemented in some transformers like `WindowSummarizer`. It has `target_cols` parameter for example. My suggestion is to unify this with all transformers by implementing in `BaseTransformer`

Btw, the reason I don't like about `FeatureUnion` approach for `selected columns` is that it could easily become a nested monster pipeline. This is hard to see, debug and would lead to  more nested param set for operations like CV.
